messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
> Picking up on your earlier post, I do agree that we should reserve the
> ligature Earth for the /3r/ sound, and use Ado + Roar in words like
> "arrest."
>

I must say however that this is no longer a ligature. That it
resembles Utter+Roe is not only accidental but destructive since it
doesn't have those sounds. Why make a ligature that looks like two
letters but never sounds like them? This is something I should hope
would remain forever relegated to T.O. Instead if it does not sound
like Utter+Roe it should not look like Utter+Roe.

What is being proposed is a new letter and I think for the purpose of
clarity it maybe more advantages to avoid the "ligature" euphemism.

So this new letter, while it may aid reading (so far as I know the
problem being addressed is only a readability problem), could greatly
impede writing. Trying to decide whether to use THAW vs THEY is a fine
example of a grapheme-phoneme separation that greatly slows writing.
And in that case, the difference is easier to perceive. Trying to
figure out which combination of Utter, Roe and Newletter to use could
be quite a slow down.

I won't bring up compatibility with old texts or the likelihood of
its sitting in the PVA indefinitely.

I admit that a new letter maybe the only way to solve the issue but it
has huge implications and I hope it can be avoided; the problem solved
would have to be correspondingly large. That said, it's certainly
worth testing and I'd love to be proven wrong.
